Expectation1: Meet sales targets set by management
Situation1: On the final day of the quarter, the team must hit the cumulative target to avoid penalties and secure bonuses.
Expectation2: Attend meetings and court sessions punctually
Situation2: They are expected at routine meetings that occur frequently
Story: The phone in my hand felt heavier than usual as I glanced at the clock—ten minutes until my advocacy meeting, but I was still at my telemarketing desk. My manager’s voice echoed in my mind: “We need three more sales to hit the target, or we all lose our bonuses.” The pressure was suffocating. I dialed another number, rehearsing my pitch, but my eyes kept darting to the calendar reminder flashing on my screen: “Advocacy meeting in 10 minutes. Attendance mandatory.” My advocacy team relied on me to be present, to speak up for our clients, and to show unwavering commitment. Missing a meeting could mean letting down people who counted on my voice. But if I left now, I’d be abandoning my telemarketing team at the most critical moment. My heart pounded as I weighed the expectations—one demanding relentless sales, the other unwavering presence. I stared at the phone, torn, feeling the walls of both worlds closing in.
